column2: Imperial rule over Sicilia, one of the last western outposts of the Empire to be lost to barbarian rule, has been reinstated yet again - this time hopefully for good.
The Province of Corsica et Sardinia

The islands of Corsica and Sardinia, originally incorporated in the empire after the First Punic War, are yet again under imperial rule. The conquest of this strategic location in the Mediterranian heralds a glorious westward expansion of the Empire.

Viennensis, named after the town Vienne in southeastern Gaul, has long been lost to Roman rule, but has now been incorporated back into the Empire. It was originally formed as a merger of the provinces Gallia Aquitania and Gallia Narbonensis created by Caesar after his campaigns had expanded the old province of Gaul too far to be administered as a single province.
